awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a  Photonic Nanofabrication System
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a photonic nanofabrication system that enables three-dimensional fabrication of nanoscale to mesoscale structures with ultrahigh print resolution.  This instrument will catalyze, potentially transformative fundamental research at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in areas ranging from soft robotics and sensors/actuators to cellular and lattice structures--enabling societal advances in areas from precision surgery and biomedical devices to manufacturing and  warehouse distribution. This instrument will be a major regional resource for nanofabrication research and training and it will enhance Embry-Riddle’s collaborations with other universities, research centers, and industries. The award will also support educational activities for K-12, undergraduate and graduate students, and the public-- significantly impacting diverse populations of all ages and backgrounds.

Recent advances in additive manufacturing provide an opportunity to design and fabricate complex microstructures with unconventional geometries and materials for a wide range of engineering applications. This instrument will enable fabrication of biofidelic and biomimetic scaffolds and micromechanical and microfluidic devices to study biochemical processes and cancer research. Key projects will advance fundamental understanding in key areas including

- electromechanical relationships between micro dielectric elastomer and compliant electrodes of soft robotic actuation and knowledge of how muscular hydrostatic actuation works.
- relationships between the optimized microstructure geometries and mechanical properties and number of cells in 3D-printed micro lattice cellular structures.

-  3D geometries that offer better loss for guided waves or improved antenna radiation and optimal dielectric interconnections that are enabled by a 3D polymer structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this National Science Foundation (NSF) Major Research Instrumentation Program grant have spanned diverse arrays across various STEM fields, including Aerospace, Mechanical, Electrical, and Biomedical domains. Key achievements include the successful fabrication and testing of micro-sized architectures for sensing and a helical dielectric elastomer actuator. In addressing challenges encountered during the incorporation of electrodes into the fabricated sensors and actuators, our research extended into exploring hydrophilic and hydrophobic surface morphologies. This endeavor aimed to facilitate the infusion of electrode solutions into the printed components, presenting an innovative approach to coat surfaces with patterned electrodes through a technique known as electrode dipping. These hydrophilic and hydrophobic surface morphologies drew inspiration from the concept of biomimicry, leading to further exploration of biomimetic avenues in our research. Notable outcomes include the development and testing of synthetic gecko setae for adhesion in space applications and the printing of synthetic scales to create highly hydrophobic surfaces.

Additionally, our research encompassed the material characterization of a novel elastomeric resin introduced by Nanoscribe GmbH. This resin, which cures through two-photon polymerization (2PP), was compared to the properties of standard Sylgard elastomer materials. On the biomedical front, nano-micro pyramids were fabricated on a sensor to enhance the detection of hazardous gases using plasmonics.

The culmination of these research endeavors has been made possible through the dedication of a diverse group of students and researchers, representing various ethnicities and genders. The dissemination of this research to multiple stakeholders, along with its presentation and incorporation into teaching materials for both undergraduate and graduate students, has served to illuminate the myriad possibilities that 3D printing offers. Our work has also been shared in workshops, including one involving Federation for Advanced Manufacturing Education scholars.

In conclusion, the outcomes of this NSF grant reflect not only the technical advancements achieved but also the broader impact on education and outreach. The innovative applications of 3D printing, particularly with the Nanoscribe PPGT2 printer, have been demonstrated and shared, paving the way for new possibilities in diverse scientific and educational realms. This project underscores the importance of interdisciplinary collaboration and the transformative potential of research inspired by biomimicry. As we reflect on these achievements, it is clear that the knowledge generated has the capacity to shape future developments in STEM fields and inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers.


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Daewon Kim
